spectra_distance module¶

Compute the fuzzy distance between centroided spectra

pactolus.spectra_distance.calc_dot_matrix(scan_list, params)[source]¶

Computes the sparse uncertain dot product for every unique pair of scans in a list of scans and returns the proximity matrix, i.e. matrix of dot products.

Parameters:
  • scan_list – list of numpy ndarrays, each of shape (n_rows, 2) with columns m/z and intensity
  • params –

    dict, has keys: ‘mass_tol’: a float with allowed mass discrepancy in Da ‘neutral_losses’: list of floats [or dict with float values],

    allowed neutral losses. When peaks in two spectra differ by any of these amounts, they are still counted as matching
    ‘noise_cutoff’: (optional) float, value below which
    intensities will be set to zero
    ‘normalize’: int or None, whether or not to normalize intensities,
    if int indicates order of norm to use. For computing dot products L2 norm should be used. For now, only values supported are 1 and 2.
    ‘want_match_matrix’: boolean, whether or not to return a matrix
    of dimension n by m, where n = n1 + n2 = number of unique masses in both spectra, and m is number of neutralizations

    ‘metric’: function to use for comparing spectra
Returns:

proximity matrix, a numpy ndarray of shape (n_scans, n_scans) of floats, non-zero only in upper triangular part
pactolus.spectra_distance.calc_lambda(mz_1, mz_2, mass_tol)[source]¶

Finds the mass-uncertainty-adjusted product of intensities between two peaks close in mass.

Parameters:
  • mz_1 – float, m/z value in Da for peak 1
  • mz_2 – float, m/z value in Da for peak 2

:param mass_tol:, float, maximum allowable mass difference in Da for two peaks to be matched. :return: lambda value, float, mass-difference-adjusted equality between two mass values. The name lambda refers to http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ac5014783, not to Python’s “lambda function” concept.

pactolus.spectra_distance.score_spectra_pairwise(mz_intensity_arr_1, mz_intensity_arr_2, params=None)[source]¶

Uses mass-tolerance-aware

Parameters:
  • mz_intensity_arr_1 – numpy nd_array with shape (n_peaks_1, 2) with columns m/z (in Da) and intensity
  • mz_intensity_arr_2 – numpy nd_array with shape (n_peaks_2, 2) with columns m/z (in Da) and intensity
  • params –

    dict, has keys: ‘mass_tol’: a float with allowed mass discrepancy in Da ‘neutral_losses’: list of floats [or dict with float values],

    allowed neutral losses. When peaks in two spectra differ by any of these amounts, they are still counted as matching
    ‘noise_cutoff’: (optional) float, value below which
    intensities will be set to zero
    ‘normalize’: int or None, whether or not to normalize intensities,
    if int indicates order of norm to use. For computing dot products L2 norm should be used. For now, only values supported are 1 and 2.
    ‘want_match_matrix’: boolean, whether or not to return a matrix
    of dimension n by m, where n = n1 + n2 = number of unique masses in both spectra, and m is number of neutralizations

    ‘metric’: function to use for comparing spectra
Returns:

score or (score, match_matrix)
pactolus.spectra_distance.sparse_uncertain_dot(mz_intensity_arr_1, mz_intensity_arr_2, mass_tol)[source]¶

Computes dot product of two (sparse) mass spectra accounting for mass uncertainty.

Parameters:
  • mz_intensity_arr_1 – numpy ndarray of shape (n_peaks_1, 2) with columns m/z and intensitiy
  • mz_intensity_arr_2 – numpy ndarray of shape (n_peaks_2, 2) with columns m/z and intensitiy
  • mass_tol – float, maximum allowable mass difference in Da for two peaks to be matched.

The name lambda refers to http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ac5014783, not to Python’s “lambda function” concept.

pactolus.spectra_distance.threshold_intensities(mz_intensity_arr, cutoff_intensity)[source]¶

Remove noise from a mass spectrum by removing all peaks below a provided intensity value

Parameters:
  • mz_intensity_arr – numpy nd_array with shape (n_peaks, 2) with columns m/z (in Da) and intensity in counts
  • cutoff_intensity – float, value (in counts i.e. same units as intensity) below which all peaks are removed
Returns:

thresholded_mz_intensity_arr
